study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of micro- and nano-bubble (MNB) treatment on the microstructure, functional properties, and rehydration characteristics of milk protein concentrate (MPC) dispersions.
results_summary: MNB treatment reduced viscosity by ~65% in MPC dispersions and improved rehydration properties of the resultant powders, with fewer large particles observed during dissolution compared to control.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on MPC dispersions and powders).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between cow's milk protein allergy (CMPA) and food protein-induced enterocolitis syndrome (FPIES) in an infant presenting with methemoglobinemia and gastrointestinal symptoms.
results_summary: The study reported a case of a three-month-old boy with poor weight gain, loose stools, and methemoglobinemia, suspected to be caused by FPIES in the context of CMPA. It highlighted the diagnostic challenges of chronic FPIES and the importance of clinical suspicion for timely intervention.
population_specificity: A three-month-old infant with gastrointestinal symptoms and methemoglobinemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of the A2 adenosine receptor (A2AR) in the development of cow's milk protein allergy (CMPA) and its potential therapeutic modulation.
results_summary: The study found that A2AR expression is downregulated in CMPA, and its activation via the agonist CGS21680 reduced allergic responses while increasing Treg cell levels, whereas the antagonist KW-6002 exacerbated allergic symptoms and decreased Treg cells.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice and CMPA patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how microwave, ultrasound, and thermosonication treatments affect the functional properties, digestibility, and structural changes of milk proteins.
results_summary: Ultrasound treatment significantly improved milk protein digestibility (90.20-94.41%) and content, while microwave treatment showed variable digestibility (72.56-93.4%) and reduced protein content at higher temperatures. Thermosonication resulted in lower digestibility (68.76-78.81%) with no clear trend in protein content.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or animal model given the abstract details).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of different pasteurization methods (HTST, HHP, HoP) on protein profile and aggregation in human milk protein concentrate (HMPC).
results_summary: Heat treatments (HTST, HoP) caused more protein denaturation and aggregation than HHP treatments, with lactoferrin concentration decreasing by 86% after HTST and HoP. HHP processing minimized structural changes, suggesting it as a preferable pasteurization method for preserving protein quality and bioactivity.
population_specificity: Human milk protein concentrate (HMPC)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of ultrasonic treatment time on the particle size, molecular weight, microstructure, and solubility of milk protein concentrate (MPC) and its impact on emulsifying properties and encapsulation efficiency.
results_summary: Ultrasonic treatment reduced particle size and improved protein solubility and emulsifying stability of MPC, with optimal treatment times of 6 minutes for MPC emulsion. The emulsifying stability of MPC was inferior to milk fat globule membrane (MPL), suggesting MPL is more suitable for simulating human fat in infant formula.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
study_duration: Ultrasonic treatment times of 3 min (MPL) and 6 min (MPC)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a semi-automated method using Detectron2 for detecting and segmenting elaiosomes in milk thistle seeds to enable high-throughput phenotyping.
results_summary: The study successfully used Detectron2 to detect and segment elaiosomes with 99.9% accuracy, facilitating analysis of seed phenotypic traits. This method supports breeding milk thistle cultivars with desirable traits.
population_specificity: Milk thistle seeds (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if fecal calprotectin levels could serve as a biological indicator for monitoring milk protein allergies in infants before and after dietary intervention.
results_summary: The study found that infants with milk protein allergies had significantly higher fecal calprotectin levels compared to nonallergic infants, and these levels decreased significantly after dietary intervention. Growth indices also improved post-intervention, suggesting a positive effect of the treatment.
population_specificity: 180 infants (90 with milk protein allergies, 90 nonallergic controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the ability of milk thistle to protect rabbits from liver toxicity caused by oxidized tallow and assess its hepatoprotective effects.
results_summary: Milk thistle supplementation normalized pro-inflammatory cytokines and antioxidant status, reduced liver fat storage, and improved liver-related inflammatory markers and serum lipid profiles in rabbits exposed to oxidized tallow.
population_specificity: Rabbits with induced liver toxicity from oxidized tallow.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of silibinin (from Milk Thistle) on diabetes and its associated complications through molecular, cellular, animal, and clinical studies.
results_summary: Silibinin improved diabetic conditions by reducing insulin resistance, oxidative stress, and inflammation while enhancing antioxidative markers and lipid profiles. It also showed benefits in treating diabetic complications like hepatic damage, neuropathy, and retinopathy.
population_specificity: Cellular and animal models of diabetes, as well as clinical studies (specific human populations not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-psoriatic effects of Milk Thistle extract, focusing on its impact on the PI3K/AKT/mTOR and KEAP1/NRF2/NF-κB pathways in mice with IMQ-induced psoriatic lesions.
results_summary: Milk Thistle extract demonstrated potent anti-psoriatic activity, reducing skin erythema, scaling, and epidermal thickening, comparable to standard cortisone treatment. It also inhibited the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway, activated NRF2 signaling, and reduced inflammatory markers like NF-κB, IL-23, and IL-17A.
population_specificity: Male Swiss albino mice with IMQ-induced psoriatic lesions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and tolerability of silymarin (derived from milk thistle) in treating gambling disorder in adults.
results_summary: Silymarin did not statistically outperform placebo on any outcome measures, with both groups showing similar reductions in gambling disorder symptoms (56% for silymarin vs. 57% for placebo). The study concluded that silymarin is not effective for treating gambling disorder but highlighted a significant placebo response.
population_specificity: Adults with gambling disorder (43 participants, mean age 49.61 years, 41.9% women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Milk Thistle extract on growth performance, health status, and economic efficiency in heat-stressed growing rabbits.
results_summary: Milk Thistle supplementation at 10-15 g/kg diet improved growth performance, feed utilization, immune response, antioxidant capacity, and liver function in heat-stressed rabbits, with optimal doses varying by specific outcome.
population_specificity: Weaned male rabbits exposed to severe heat stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of milk thistle (MT) and nano-milk thistle (N-MT) on apoptosis and cell cycle regulation in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cell lines (Huh-7 and HepG2).
results_summary: N-MT significantly reduced cancer cell growth, induced apoptosis, and altered gene expression related to cell cycle and apoptosis pathways, while MT showed no significant effects. N-MT was more effective than MT, particularly in upregulating pro-apoptotic genes and downregulating anti-apoptotic genes.
population_specificity: Hepatocellular carcinoma cell lines (Huh-7 and HepG2).
effective_dosage: IC50 values: Huh-7 (2.35 μg/ml at 24h, 1.7 μg/ml at 48h), HepG2 (3.4 μg/ml at 24h, 2.6 μg/ml at 48h).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the extraction techniques, quality, efficacy, and safety of milk thistle supplements, focusing on silymarin content and potential adulteration.
results_summary: The study found that silymarin, the main bioactive component of milk thistle, is safe and well-tolerated in appropriate doses, but commercial preparations often lack recommended concentrations, reducing therapeutic effects. Toxic contaminants and adulteration were also detected in some products.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of milk thistle supplements).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the experimental evidence of milk thistle's effects on animals when administered as silymarin extract or a feed ingredient, focusing on health and performance outcomes.
results_summary: Milk thistle improved animal performance, product quality, oxidative stability, liver function, gut health, and reduced intestinal pathogens in farm animals. It also supported liver disease treatment in dogs and cats and showed positive effects in equine athletes and aquaculture. No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Farm animals, dogs, cats, equine athletes, and aquaculture species.
effective_dosage: Not clearly reported in all studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a fermented milk containing silybin and protein from milk thistle seeds, making it applicable for the food industry.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a fermented milk with high silybin (11.24-12.14 mg/g seeds) and protein (121.8-129.6 mg/g seeds) yields, achieving 72.6-78.4% of total silybin extraction from seeds. The product had a slightly sweet yoghurt-like flavor and could serve as a dietary supplement.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or food product development study).
effective_dosage: Optimal NaHCO3 treatment: 1% NaHCO3, 60°C, 3 h; fermentation strains: L131 and RS72.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent patents and literature on the anticancer and hepatoprotective effects of Milk Thistle (Silybum marianum) and its extract, silymarin.
results_summary: Milk thistle and silymarin demonstrated chemopreventive effects against cancers (e.g., skin, prostate, colorectal) and hepatoprotective properties, potentially reactivating cell death pathways and modulating antiapoptotic proteins. Silymarin may also help mitigate side effects of anticancer chemotherapeutics.
population_specificity: Not specified (patent and literature review, not a clinical study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the health protective effects of dietary milk thistle seed, oil, and seed cake in ducks fed diets contaminated with deoxynivalenol (DON) and zearalenone (ZEN).
results_summary: The study found that milk thistle treatments effectively prevented histopathological changes caused by DON and ZEN, with milk thistle oil showing superior effects on vacuolar hepatocyte degeneration. All treatments were equally effective in reducing liver cell death and immune cell infiltration, as well as preventing lymphocyte depletion in immune organs.
population_specificity: Female White Hungarian ducks
effective_dosage: 0.5% milk thistle seed (MS), 0.5% milk thistle seed cake (MSC), or 0.1% milk thistle oil (MO)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of milk thistle extract administered in drinking water on chickens' welfare, production results, enzymatic activity, and antioxidant capacity.
results_summary: The study found that milk thistle improved chickens' welfare, production results, enzymatic activity, and antioxidant capacity in blood serum and pectoral muscle, with statistically significant results (p ≤ 0.05).
population_specificity: One-day-old male ROSS 308 chicks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of Silymarin (milk thistle) supplementation on liver health markers in morbidly obese NAFLD patients undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Silymarin significantly improved AST/ALT ratio, BMI, and sonographic grading but showed no significant effect on fibroscan staging, Fib-4, and NAFLD scores. No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients (mean BMI 47.84 kg/m²) with NAFLD, candidates for bariatric surgery (41 women, 11 men; mean age 38.9 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects and mechanisms of milk thistle in treating nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in type 2 diabetic rats.
results_summary: Milk thistle significantly improved oxidative stress markers, liver function tests, and lipid profiles, and protected against histological liver changes in diabetic rats with NAFLD. However, glucose tolerance improvements were nonsignificant.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic rats with induced NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pharmacological properties of milk thistle, its role in systemic and oral diseases, and summarize existing evidence on its therapeutic potential.
results_summary: The study found that milk thistle, particularly silymarin, exhibits antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, anticancer, antifungal, and immunomodulatory properties, with promising effects in oral diseases like periodontal disease, dental caries, and oral cancer, though human research is limited.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature)
effective_dosage: Not specified (summary of previously used doses mentioned but not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether salicylic acid (SA) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) treatments could mitigate cadmium (Cd+2) toxicity in milk thistle plants grown in two different ecological zones.
results_summary: SA and H2O2 treatments significantly improved growth attributes, photosynthetic pigments, and secondary metabolites in milk thistle under Cd+2 stress, while reducing oxidative damage markers like MDA and H2O2. The effects were more pronounced at lower altitudes.
population_specificity: Milk thistle plants (Silybum marianum L. Gaertn) grown in Quetta (high altitude) and Turbat (low altitude) in Balochistan Province, Pakistan.
effective_dosage: SA (0.25 μM), H2O2 (10 μM), and Cd+2 (500 μM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the mechanistic pathways and downstream targets of silymarin in the therapy of gastrointestinal cancer, focusing on its chemoprotective and anti-cancer effects.
results_summary: Silymarin demonstrated liver-protective, chemopreventive, anti-metastatic, and anti-inflammatory activities, with potential to reduce chemotherapy and radiotherapy side effects while enhancing anti-cancer effects, particularly in gastrointestinal cancers.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro, in vivo, and clinical studies referenced broadly).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Milk Thistle seed oil (MTSO) could counteract the pro-oxidative and pro-apoptotic effects of 7β-hydroxycholesterol (7β-OHC) in human neuroblastoma cells.
results_summary: MTSO (100 µg/mL) significantly attenuated oxidative damage caused by 7β-OHC, reducing ROS production, lipid/protein oxidation, and caspase 3 activation, demonstrating strong cytoprotective effects.
population_specificity: Human neuroblastoma cells (SH-SY5Y) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically evaluate the efficacy and safety of milk thistle in preventing anti-tuberculosis drug-induced liver injury.
results_summary: The study found that milk thistle demonstrated efficacy in reducing the incidence of liver injury and improving bilirubin and liver enzyme levels, providing evidence-based support for its clinical use.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing anti-tuberculosis treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of salinity stress and plant growth promoters (PGPs) on the yield, quality, and silymarin content of Milk Thistle ecotypes with varying achene colors.
results_summary: Salinity stress reduced yield-related attributes but increased secondary metabolites and pericarp structures. PGPs (ascorbic acid, thiourea, and moringa leaf extract) mitigated salinity effects and improved Milk Thistle quality and quantity, with the Quetta ecotype showing higher silymarin extraction under stress.
population_specificity: Milk Thistle ecotypes from Faisalabad, Gujranwala, Quetta, and Kallar Kahar under controlled salinity stress conditions.
effective_dosage: Ascorbic acid (500 µM), moringa leaf extract (3%), thiourea (250 µM) applied via soil after salinity stress induction.
study_duration: Intervention applied at the germination stage; exact duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether feeding milk thistle seed cakes could positively affect the health of horses, particularly in relation to liver disease and laminitis.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in AST, NEFA, cortisol, and Pi levels in horses fed milk thistle seed cakes, suggesting potential positive health effects. Exercise also influenced albumin, lactate, cortisol, NEFA, and calcium levels.
population_specificity: Horses (n = 10, with 5 in the experimental group and 5 in the control group) bred and trained under similar conditions.
effective_dosage: Up to 400 g/day of milk thistle seed cakes, fed twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize cases of mycotoxin contamination in Milk Thistle-based dietary supplements and emphasize the need for stricter monitoring and regulation.
results_summary: The study highlights the hepatoprotective effects of silymarin in Milk Thistle but notes that its benefits can be reduced or negated by mycotoxin contamination, particularly from Fusarium and Alternaria genera. The abstract calls for regulatory attention as current EU legislation does not cover mycotoxins in Milk Thistle supplements.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on Milk Thistle-based dietary supplements).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Milk Thistle cold press oil (MTO) could mitigate cardiovascular and metabolic complications induced by a high-fat diet in obese mice.
results_summary: MTO treatment reduced obesity, fasting hyperglycemia, hypertension, inflammation, and liver fibrosis while promoting mitochondrial fusion and browning of white adipose tissue in mice fed a high-fat diet.
population_specificity: Obese mice fed a high-fat diet for 20 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether milk thistle seed supplementation could protect poultry against oxidative stress induced by mycotoxins (DON and ZEA).
results_summary: Milk thistle supplementation showed cytoprotective effects, activated the antioxidant system, and reduced oxidative stress markers, though it unexpectedly elevated lipid peroxidation products. The mycotoxin-contaminated diet alone also triggered an effective antioxidant response.
population_specificity: White, female, Hungarian ducks
effective_dosage: 0.5% pressed milk thistle seed in feed

study_goal: The researchers aimed to document a first case of allergy to Milk Thistle (Silybum marianum) and assess its potential as a new allergen.
results_summary: The study identified Milk Thistle as a potential allergen, with the patient exhibiting allergic reactions (itching, swelling, respiratory symptoms) upon exposure. No prior similar cases were found in the literature.
population_specificity: A 29-year-old male with occupational exposure to Milk Thistle and teff.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Milk Thistle (Silybum marianum) could protect against vancomycin-induced nephrotoxicity by reducing oxidative stress and apoptosis in kidney cells.
results_summary: The study found that Milk Thistle extract reduced mRNA expression of apoptotic genes (p53, p21, cyt-c) and alleviated kidney damage in mice treated with vancomycin, as evidenced by lower serum urea/creatinine levels and improved histopathology.
population_specificity: Vero cells (monkey kidney cells) and mice.
interactions: Vancomycin (protective effect observed when co-administered with Milk Thistle).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the composition, chemical safety, and biological safety of 26 milk thistle-based dietary supplements from the U.S. and Czech markets.
results_summary: The study found large variations in silymarin content among preparations, often inconsistent with manufacturer claims, and detected significant contamination by mycotoxins, pesticides, and microbiological agents, raising serious safety concerns.
population_specificity: Not specified (commercial milk thistle supplements from U.S. and Czech markets).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether milk thistle interacts with warfarin in vivo, based on prior in vitro evidence suggesting CYP2C9-mediated interactions.
results_summary: The study reported an increase in INR (from 2.64 to 4.12) in a patient taking warfarin after starting a milk thistle supplement, which normalized upon discontinuation of the supplement. This suggests a potential interaction between milk thistle and warfarin.
population_specificity: A White Hispanic man in his 30s on warfarin therapy for mitral valve replacement.
effective_dosage: 200 mg (as part of a 'liver cleanse' supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of silymarin (Milk Thistle) in preventing antituberculosis drug-induced liver injury (anti-TB DILI).
results_summary: Silymarin significantly reduced the occurrence of anti-TB DILI at week 4 and improved liver function markers (ALT, AST, ALP) in patients receiving anti-TB drugs, with similar adverse event rates compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing antituberculosis drug therapy (total of 1198 patients from five RCTs).
study_duration: At least 4 weeks (primary outcome measured at week 4).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and tolerability of silymarin (Milk Thistle) in children and adults with trichotillomania.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant improvement on the primary outcome measure, but Milk Thistle showed significant improvements on select secondary measures, such as time spent pulling per day and Clinical Global Impression severity.
population_specificity: 20 individuals (19 women, 16 adults; mean age 27.9 years) with trichotillomania.
effective_dosage: 150 mg to 300 mg twice a day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Silibinin, a compound from Milk Thistle, stimulates leukocyte differentiation in mouse embryonic stem cells and its association with vasculogenesis.
results_summary: Silibinin treatment increased leukocyte/macrophage differentiation markers (CD18+, CD45+, CD68+) and activated key signaling pathways (PI3K/AKT, STAT3, HIF-1α, VEGFR2). The effects were abolished by specific inhibitors, indicating these pathways regulate Silibinin-induced differentiation.
population_specificity: Mouse embryonic stem cells
effective_dosage: Hydrosoluble Silibinin-C-2',3-dihydrogen succinate (dose-dependent, exact amounts not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether silibinin, a compound from Milk Thistle, inhibits cardiomyogenesis in embryonic stem cells by interfering with angiotensin II signaling downstream of the AT1 receptor.
results_summary: Silibinin treatment reduced cardiomyogenesis markers (spontaneously contracting cardiac foci, cardiac cell areas, contraction frequency, and Ca2+ spiking) in embryonic stem cells, counteracting the stimulatory effects of angiotensin II. It acted downstream of the AT1 receptor by inhibiting ERK1/2, JNK, and p38 MAPK pathways.
population_specificity: Differentiating embryonic stem cells and rat smooth muscle cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a water-soluble microencapsulated milk thistle extract to improve silymarin's bioactivity and evaluate its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: The microencapsulated system improved in vitro dissolution and permeation rates, maintained antioxidant activity under harsh storage conditions, and preserved anti-inflammatory effects at low concentrations (0.312 mg/mL) in reducing dendritic cell cytokine secretion.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize animal and human studies on the effects of S. marianum (milk thistle) on metabolic syndrome and identify its mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study found that S. marianum exhibits antioxidant, lipid-lowering, antihypertensive, antidiabetic, antiatherosclerotic, anti-obesity, and hepatoprotective effects, suggesting potential benefits for metabolic syndrome.
population_specificity: Animal and human studies (specific populations not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the protective effects of Milk Thistle (Silybum marianum) and its main component, silymarin, against various biological and chemical toxins.
results_summary: The study found that Milk Thistle and silymarin exhibit protective properties against toxins through mechanisms like radical scavenging, anti-oxidative effects, chelation, anti-apoptotic properties, and regulation of inflammatory responses. These effects were observed against a range of biological (e.g., mycotoxins, snake venoms) and chemical (e.g., metals, pesticides) agents.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential therapeutic effects of milk thistle in oncology patients, focusing on its use as a supportive therapy for attenuating side effects of cancer treatments or as an anticarcinogenic agent.
results_summary: The study found that milk thistle, particularly its active component silymarin, may benefit oncology patients by reducing hepatotoxicity and radiotherapy-induced skin and mucosa damage at dosages of 160-600 mg daily. Evidence is supported by in vitro, animal, and increasing clinical studies, though more research is needed.
population_specificity: Oncology patients, particularly those experiencing side effects from anticancer chemotherapeutics or radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the policosanol content, antioxidant, and anti-arthritic activities of milk thistle oil extracted at different stages of seed maturation.
results_summary: Milk thistle oil from immature seeds had the highest policosanol content and exhibited the strongest antioxidant and anti-arthritic activities, with significant inhibition of protein denaturation and high radical scavenging capacity. The study found a strong correlation between policosanol content and these biological activities.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using seed oil extracts).
effective_dosage: Not specified (oil extracted from seeds at different maturation stages).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hepatoprotective properties of Korean milk thistle extracts and isolated flavonoids against oxidative stress in HepG2 cells.
results_summary: The study found that MeOH extracts and flavonoids from Korean milk thistle significantly reduced oxidative damage, increased cell viability, and restored glutathione levels in HepG2 cells, while also upregulating Nrf-2 and HO-1 protein expression.
population_specificity: HepG2 cells (human liver cancer cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of milk thistle (alone or combined with ursodeoxycholic acid) on hepatic stem cell activation and cholestasis-induced liver injury in rats.
results_summary: Milk thistle significantly reduced liver injury markers (ALT, AST, MDA) and stem cell markers (c-Kit, c-Myc, Oct3/4, SSEA-1) in cholestatic rats, with the combination of milk thistle and ursodeoxycholic acid showing the greatest reduction in ALT levels.
population_specificity: Female Sprague Dawley rats with bile duct ligation (BDL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate an analytical method for quantifying flavonolignans in milk thistle seeds and finished products.
results_summary: The optimized method demonstrated high repeatability, accuracy, and selectivity for flavonolignan quantification, with flavonolignan content ranging widely in raw materials and finished products. The method is recommended for official adoption due to its suitability for analyzing milk thistle and multicomponent products.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on analytical method validation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of potassium sulfate fertilizer doses on polyphenol content, nutrient elements, antioxidant, and antimicrobial activities of milk thistle.
results_summary: The study found that milk thistle seed and seed oils exhibited antimicrobial activity against E. coli, A. niger, and P. aeruginosa, with the highest activity observed at 90 kg ha⁻¹ K2SO4. Extracts also showed high DPPH scavenging activity, and the seeds were rich in K⁺, Ca²⁺, PO₄³⁻, and Cl⁻.
population_specificity: Milk thistle plants grown in experimental fields of Ordu University, Turkey.
effective_dosage: Potassium sulfate doses of 0, 30, 60, 90, and 120 kg ha⁻¹ were applied.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dietary supplementation with varying levels of milk thistle on growth performance, oxidative stress, and immune response in summer-stressed broilers.
results_summary: The study found that milk thistle at 15 g/kg significantly improved feed intake, body weight, feed conversion ratio, dressing percentage, and antibody titer while reducing malondialdehyde levels, indicating reduced oxidative stress. No significant effect was observed on paraoxonase activity.
population_specificity: 1-day-old broiler chicks exposed to natural summer stress.
effective_dosage: 5 g/kg, 10 g/kg, and 15 g/kg of milk thistle in feed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Silybum marianum flower extract (SMFE) possesses antiglycation activity and its potential anti-aging effects on skin.
results_summary: SMFE inhibited glycation between BSA and glucose, reduced CML expression, and stimulated fibrillin-1 expression in human skin explants, with silibinin identified as the active ingredient. The antiglycation effects were dose-dependent.
population_specificity: Human skin explants (in vitro model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal conditions for extracting oil, flavonolignans, and fatty acids from milk thistle seeds using SC-CO2 technology and to evaluate the antioxidant and cytotoxic activities of the extracts.
results_summary: The study found that SC-CO2 extraction at 220 bars and 40°C was optimal for recovering oil (30.8%) and flavonolignans, with linoleic and oleic acids being predominant. The extract showed high antioxidant activity and dose-responsive cytotoxic effects against Caco-2 cells, inducing up to 71% mortality at 100 μg/ml.
population_specificity: Caco-2 carcinoma cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the inhibitory effects of milk thistle constituents on the intestinal glucuronidation of raloxifene, a chemopreventive agent for breast cancer.
results_summary: The study found that milk thistle constituents, particularly silybin A and silybin B, potently inhibited raloxifene glucuronidation in human intestinal microsomes and cell lysates, predicting a 4- to 5-fold increase in raloxifene systemic exposure, indicating high interaction risk.
population_specificity: Women at high risk of developing breast cancer taking raloxifene.
interactions: High interaction risk with raloxifene due to inhibition of intestinal UDP-glucuronosyl transferases (UGTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the phenolic compounds in milk thistle and artichoke extracts and infusions to evaluate their bioactive potential.
results_summary: Milk thistle infusions and hydromethanolic extracts showed similar phenolic compositions, with apigenin-7-O-glucuronide as the major flavonoid. Infusions of both plants had higher phenolic content than extracts, suggesting they are a good source of bioactive compounds.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of milk thistle extract (ETHIS-094™) on liver weight, liver-to-body weight ratio, and NAFLD activity score in a NASH-induced animal model.
results_summary: Milk thistle administration significantly reduced liver weight and liver-to-body weight ratio at high doses and showed a decreasing trend in NAFLD activity and steatosis scores compared to the vehicle group.
population_specificity: Male mice with induced NASH.
effective_dosage: 500 mg/kg and 1,000 mg/kg, administered once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of Silitidil, a standardized milk thistle extract, on serum prolactin levels in female rats.
results_summary: Silitidil increased serum prolactin levels in a dose-dependent manner in female rats; this effect was not enhanced by galega and was partially reversed by bromocriptine, suggesting dopamine D2 receptor involvement.
population_specificity: Female rats
interactions: Bromocriptine reduced Silitidil-induced prolactin elevation; galega had no effect.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a standardized milk thistle supplement on major cytochrome P450 drug-metabolizing enzymes after a 14-day exposure period.
results_summary: The study found that milk thistle extract had no significant influence on the activities of CYP1A2, CYP2C9, CYP2D6, or CYP3A4/5 enzymes. The three most abundant flavonolignans in plasma were silybin A, silybin B, and isosilybin B, but their presence did not alter drug metabolism.
population_specificity: Nine healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: Standardized milk thistle extract given thrice daily (specific dosage not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether milk thistle seed extract could protect against cocaine-induced cellular toxicity in astroglial, liver, and kidney cells, as well as in shrimp larvae.
results_summary: Milk thistle pretreatment protected astroglial cells from cocaine-induced damage, maintained cell morphology, increased viability, and restored glutathione levels. It also showed high free-radical scavenging activity and was non-toxic to the cells.
population_specificity: Astroglial, liver, and kidney cells in vitro, and shrimp larvae in vivo.
study_duration: 30 minutes pretreatment followed by 1-hour cocaine exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential, safety, and pharmacological effects of silymarin (derived from Milk Thistle) across various medical conditions.
results_summary: Silymarin demonstrated low toxicity, strong antioxidant and detoxifying effects, and potential applications in treating neurodegenerative diseases, cancers, and metabolic disorders, with side effects similar to placebo. It also showed promise as a neuro-, nephro-, and cardio-protective agent, along with fetoprotective and prolactin effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (broad therapeutic applications mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the PPARγ activation potential of silymarin (from Milk Thistle) and its main constituents, particularly focusing on its role as a potential modulator of glucose and lipid metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that isosilybin A, a constituent of silymarin, activated PPARγ in a concentration-dependent manner, an effect reversible by a PPARγ antagonist. In silico docking studies suggested a unique binding mode for isosilybin A, identifying it as the first flavonolignan PPARγ agonist.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in silico study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of silymarin (from milk thistle) in treating osteoporosis and promoting bone fracture healing, particularly in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Silymarin demonstrated antioxidant properties, improved tibial healing in a mouse model, elevated bone mineral density (BMD), and increased serum levels of ALP and osteocalcin. It also showed estrogenic antiosteoporotic effects, suggesting potential benefits for bone loss prevention and fracture healing.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (primary focus) and a mouse fracture healing model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an oral milk thistle extract enriched with silibinin meglumine could inhibit the growth of non-small-cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC) xenografts and impede the epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT).
results_summary: The study found that silibinin meglumine significantly reduced NSCLC tumor volumes, comparable to the EGFR TKI gefitinib, and prevented regrowth of gefitinib-unresponsive tumors. It also effectively impeded EMT markers in vitro and in vivo.
population_specificity: Mouse xenografts of non-small-cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the osteoprotective effects of Milk Thistle extract (MTE) and its component silibinin on preventing estrogen deficiency-induced bone loss in a postmenopausal osteopenia model.
results_summary: MTE and silibinin improved femoral bone mineral density, reduced osteoclastogenic stimulus, and inhibited bone loss by suppressing TRAP activity and cathepsin K induction, showing effects comparable to estrogenic isoflavone. The low-dose combination of MTE and isoflavone exhibited pharmacological synergy for osteogenic activity.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized C57BL/6 female mice (postmenopausal osteopenia model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the silymarin content, antioxidant activities, and antiviral activity against HCV in commercially available Milk Thistle supplements.
results_summary: The study found significant variability in silymarin content among products, with some containing none or very low concentrations while others had over 80%. Both antioxidant and anti-HCV activity correlated with silymarin levels.
population_specificity: Commercially available Milk Thistle supplements (no human subjects).

study_goal: To determine the maximum tolerated daily dose of silybin phosphatidylcholine (Siliphos) in patients with advanced hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and hepatic dysfunction.
results_summary: Serum concentrations of silibinin and its metabolite increased, but liver function abnormalities and tumor markers progressed in all patients. One patient showed slight improvement in liver function after day 56, but all participants died within 23-69 days, possibly due to hepatic failure or the study drug.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced HCC and poor hepatic function, ineligible for other therapies.
effective_dosage: 2 g per day in divided doses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Milk Thistle could inhibit PXR-mediated CYP3A4 induction, potentially preventing drug-drug interactions in cancer therapy.
results_summary: Milk Thistle, specifically its components silybin and isosilybin, strongly inhibited PXR-mediated CYP3A4 induction. Computational and experimental assays confirmed their interaction with PXR, suggesting potential as PXR antagonists.
population_specificity: LS180 colon adenocarcinoma cells (in vitro study).
interactions: Potential interaction with CYP3A4-metabolized drugs due to PXR antagonism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the beneficial effects of silibinin, the active ingredient in milk thistle, on hepatic diseases, focusing on antioxidant properties, toxin protection, and anti-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: Silibinin increased antioxidant concentrations, improved outcomes in hepatic diseases caused by oxidant injury, and showed protective effects against hepatic toxins, reducing inflammation and fibrosis. Limited veterinary data was noted, warranting further study.
population_specificity: Human and potential veterinary applications (domestic animals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary silibinin supplementation, alone or combined with ethanol, on hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) progression in a mouse model.
results_summary: Silibinin showed marginal hepatoprotective effects in early HCC stages but exacerbated ethanol's promotional effects on HCC progression in male mice. No significant benefit was observed when combined with ethanol.
population_specificity: DEN-initiated HCC mouse model (male mice specifically noted for interaction effects).
interactions: Exacerbated HCC progression when co-administered with ethanol in males.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether silymarin (milk thistle extract) could reduce liver disease activity in patients with chronic hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection who had previously failed interferon-based therapy.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in serum ALT levels, HCV RNA levels, or quality-of-life measures between silymarin (at 420 mg or 700 mg doses) and placebo groups after 24 weeks of treatment. Adverse events were comparable to placebo, indicating safety but lack of efficacy.
population_specificity: 154 individuals with chronic HCV infection and elevated serum ALT levels (≥65 U/L) who had unsuccessful prior interferon-based therapy.
effective_dosage: 420 mg or 700 mg silymarin, administered 3 times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether milk thistle (silymarin) interacts with the antiretroviral combination darunavir-ritonavir in HIV-infected patients.
results_summary: Silymarin was well tolerated and did not significantly alter darunavir pharmacokinetics, suggesting no need for dose adjustment. The geometric mean ratios for key pharmacokinetic parameters indicated minimal impact of silymarin on darunavir levels.
population_specificity: HIV-infected patients receiving antiretroviral therapy with darunavir-ritonavir.
interactions: None mentioned beyond the studied interaction with darunavir-ritonavir.
